name: Citroën Xsara WRC
details_html: Driven by Sébastien Loeb, the Xsara WRC dominated the early 2000s. Agile on tarmac and fast on gravel, it secured Citroën’s rise to power and Loeb’s first titles.

name: Subaru Impreza WRC 2003–2008
details_html: Subaru’s updated Impreza featured aggressive aero and reliability. It helped Petter Solberg win the 2003 title and remained competitive until Subaru’s WRC exit in 2008.

name: Peugeot 206 WRC
details_html: Compact and light, the 206 WRC won two titles with Marcus Grönholm in 2000 and 2002, dominating twisty gravel and narrow tarmac with ease.

name: Ford Focus RS WRC 03/04/06/07
details_html: Ford’s Focus RS WRC series evolved into one of the most successful 2000s platforms, driven by Colin McRae, Marcus Grönholm, and Mikko Hirvonen.

name: Citroën C4 WRC
details_html: Successor to the Xsara, the C4 WRC carried Loeb through the second half of the 2000s. It was flawless on tarmac and brutally efficient everywhere else.

name: Skoda Fabia WRC
details_html: Skoda’s Fabia WRC entered with high hopes but struggled to match the front-runners. Still, it laid groundwork for future rally success in lower classes.

name: Hyundai Accent WRC
details_html: Hyundai’s first WRC attempt in the early 2000s wasn’t a title threat, but the Accent WRC showed moments of promise before the program was paused in 2003.

name: Suzuki SX4 WRC
details_html: Suzuki entered WRC in 2008 with the SX4 WRC — a solid but short-lived entry that struggled to reach the podium before the program ended.

name: Mitsubishi Lancer WRC 04–06
details_html: Mitsubishi returned with the Lancer WRC, but without Tommi Mäkinen and with limited factory support, it couldn’t recapture its 90s glory.

name: Ford Fiesta RS WRC
details_html: The Fiesta RS WRC debuted in 2011, but its development began in the late 2000s. It became a competitive force in the WRC, especially with M-Sport.
